newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan pension fund body suspends deals with Nomura.
newsitem.headline: Japan pension fund body suspends deals with Nomura.

text.p: Japan's Pension Welfare Service Public Corp, an affiliate of the Health Ministry, said on Wednesday it had temporarily suspended its Japanese government bond dealings with Nomura Securities Co Ltd.
"We are temporarily suspending new deals in Japanese government bonds with Nomura," said an official at the pension fund body.

Nomura has come under fire since admitting last week that two of its executives were involved in suspected illegal deals. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission (SESC) has launched a probe into the incident.
The pension body will not take further steps until the results of the SESC's investigation are made public, he added.
As a result of the business suspension, the pension fund body will look to other securities houses and banks when it decides to invest its money in Japanese government bonds, he said.

Nomura said last week that two of its directors had made deals that appeared to be "discretionary" transactions, meaning they were done without the client's knowledge, and moved profits raised from Nomura's own funds into a corporate client's account, practices banned under Japan's securities law. Media reports have linked the corporate client with a former "sokaiya" racketeer.
